title: WCAS SLAVIC 322-0-1 Making a Dictionary: The Northwestern Project

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Northwestern University is a community, working to set goals, achieve them, defining and striving for excellence, etc. As such we create a culture and are a speech community using our language to describe and form our culture and identity. This language includes jargon (such as: freshman seminars and advisers, Wildcat, distros, CAESAR, CTECs, DM, ASG, SafeRide, MMLC, and many, many more), as well as slang (such as: rapey, getting raped on an exam, I'm just sayin', LOLOLOL, gotta bounce, and many, many more), etc. Where interest and ability, bilingual/multilingual versions of the dictionary may also be possible for students to create. SLAVIC 322/LING 363 concentrates on the language, identity, and heritage of the Northwestern University community. Students will continue to create the digital-born Northwestern online dictionary "WildWords" https://nudictionary.mmlc.northwestern.edu/wiki/index.php/Main_Page documenting NU's language. Students will learn to conduct, collect, and analyze the language as well as create the dictionary (sociolinguistic fieldwork and lexicography). Students will also learn about the role, status, and prejudice that book-dictionaries have had in history (drawing on readings from specifically Russianin translationand English language examples) and work to try to avoid such prejudices in the Northwestern Dictionary Project. Moreover, students will engage in meaningful reflection and discussion on the "monopoly of the printed book" in light of emerging, digital forms as represented by dictionaries (printed and digital ones). The Northwestern Dictionary Project is about lexicography, linguistics, identity, culture, and heritage. It offers a venue for community building as well as a common networking space for meanings of NU's language for students, staff, and faculty

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Fulfills Area III Social and Behavioral Sciences Distribution Requirement

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: 1) How people of a speech community use language to express identity and how people think about themselves affects the way that they talk. 2) The social and linguistic prejudice of dictionaries. The symbolic role that a dictionary and the book-form have in defining, shaping, and influencing a society, which includes not only what language and whose language is included (e.g. does ain't belong in the dictionary and with what type of definition), but also how can the physical form of a dictionary contribute to its role and power (for example, whether print-book or digital form). 3) Whether the digital medium changes the way we think, use, feel, design, and create dictionaries, and what effects does this perhaps have on the conventional standards of the prestige, authority, and power wielded by the traditional editorial-board-driven print-book dictionaries? 4) An understanding of the fields of lexicography and sociolinguistic fieldwork. 5) A working understanding of designing and creating an online e-dictionary.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Flipped and hybrid class: some lecture, student led lectures & discussions, some direction of the class decided on by students, also in class collaborate working sessions ("coffeeshop time")

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Flipped and hybrid: peer evaluations, blog assignments, participation in collaborate work and discussions, dictionary entries in or other dictionary contributions to WildWords (Northwestern's online dictionary)

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Most materials for reading & reviewing will be pdfs, videos, or other online materials available online through the course's Canvas Course Management Site.

Two e-books are required:
Mugglestone, Lynda. 2011. Dictionaries: A Very Short Introduction. (Series title: Very Short Introductions). Oxford University Press.

Edwards, John. 2013. Sociolinguistics: A Very Short Introduction. (Series title: Very Short Introductions). Oxford University Press.

Both of these are available in Kindle form from Amazon, but other e-versions are also acceptable.
